Ni-ZSM-5 catalysts with different Ni loadings were synthesized by the one-pot method, using ethylenediamine as a complex agent to prevent precipitation during the hydrothermal synthesis. The effect of nickel content and synthesis time on the crystallinity of the solids was characterized by X-ray diffraction. The results showed that an increase in the synthesis time was needed to obtain catalysts with high crystallinity. The increment in the reduction temperature for the catalyst with lower Ni content indicated the formation of Ni species with higher interaction with the support. All the solids were active for the dry reforming of methane, showing the catalyst with 1.3 wt.% of Ni superior activity per gram of Ni and lower carbon formation. This catalyst was stable under the DRM reaction even after 48 h. The performance of this solid could be attributed to the greater confinement of Ni crystallites within the support, which improved metal support interaction, as evidenced by temperature-programmed reduction and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy and suggested by transmission electron microscopy. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane One-pot synthesis Zeolite ZSM-5 Hydrothermal synthesis Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In the last decades, the dry reforming of methane (DRM) has gained interest in hydrogen and/or synthesis gas production since it involves two greenhouse gases (CO2 and CH4) as reactants. The synthesis gas produced from the DRM has an H2/CO ratio ≤1, suitable for the production of synthetic fuels (Fischer-Tropsch) [1]. Moreover, the discovery of new unconventional natural gas reserves and biogas production has further motivated the study of this reaction [2]. The DRM, a highly endothermic reaction, is represented by the following equation: (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ⇌ 2 CO + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 ∘ = 247 kJmol − 1 Among the reforming reaction, the following secondary reactions can occur, depending on the operation conditions: (2) CO 2 + H 2 ⇌ CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 ∘ = 41 kJmol − 1 (3) C H 4 ⇌ C * + 2 H 2 Δ H ∘ = 75 kJmo l − 1 (4) 2 CO ⇌ C * + C O 2 Δ H ∘ = − 172 kJmol − 1 Catalysts based on noble metals such as Pt, Ru, Rh, and Ir and transition metals such as Ni and Co have been used for the DRM [3]. Recently, there has appeared an increasing interest in developing nickel-based catalysts due to their low cost despite their increased susceptibility to deactivation by coking or sintering [4]. On the other hand, different supports have been used to stabilize the active phase, improving the metal-support interaction [5]. Other supports based on zeolites have also been studied due to their significant properties, such as high surface area, molecular pore dimensions, crystallinity, and thermal stability [6,7], which can be appropriate for different applications in catalysis [8,9]. An alternative that has been extensively investigated is the incorporation of the active phase into zeolites through post-synthesis methods such as ion exchange or impregnation. Nevertheless, the direct incorporation of the metal precursor into the synthesis gel and subsequent zeolite crystallization has been proposed as an alternative method [10]. With this method, it is possible to achieve good stability, high dispersion, and control of the metal particle size, achieving higher metal-support interaction and avoiding the deactivation of the catalyst during the reaction. However, during the synthesis of zeolites, the pH and temperature can induce cation precipitation, making their incorporation into the zeolite structure difficult. Different ligand agents can be used to avoid cation precipitation, improving the direct incorporation of various metals into the zeolite. This approach has allowed the selective encapsulation of a wide range of metals (Pt, Pd, Ir, Rh, and Ag) into LTA zeolites [11] and Ni, Co, and Fe oxides in LTA, MFI, and FAU zeolites by hydrothermal treatment [12], Au in LTA and MFI zeolites [13], and Pt encapsulated into NaA zeolite [14]. Likewise, several studies have reported the direct incorporation of noble metals in the ZSM-5 zeolite [15,16] and applied them to reactions such as hydrodeoxygenation of phenolics [17], catalytic conversion of fatty acids [18], and hydropirolysis of biomass to light aromatics [19]. Different zeolite structures have been studied as support materials for the dry reforming of methane [20]. Among them, the ZSM-5 zeolite presents two types of channels: straight ones with a 0.53 × 0.56 nm section, which are interconnected with sinusoidal channels with an elliptical section of 0.51 × 0.55 nm, which convert it into a promising support to explore in the DRM. Bawah et al. [21] reported modified Ni-silicalite-1 catalysts by exchange with Ce, Y, or Zn through microwave-assisted hydrothermal synthesis, which made catalyst Ni-S-1 more stable and selective, reducing carbon formation. Estephane et al. [22] synthesized monometallic Ni, Co, and bimetallic Ni-Co catalysts on ZSM-5 through the wet impregnation method. The bimetallic catalyst presented higher catalytic performance and less carbon formation due to the presence of cobalt. On the other hand, Coelho et al. [23] synthesized Ni/HZSM-5 catalysts with 3 wt.% and 5 wt.% by incipient-wetness impregnation and then through post-synthesis treatments, such as alkaline desilication, they obtained catalysts resistant to coke formation and sintering. However, to our knowledge, no studies have reported ZSM-5-based catalysts synthesized through the direct incorporation method of the active phase that have been evaluated in the dry reforming of methane. This work studied the experimental conditions for incorporating the active phase through one-pot synthesis without adding a directing agent or template to synthesize the Ni-ZSM-5 catalysts. The materials were evaluated in the dry reforming of methane, and their catalytic properties were correlated with the physicochemical properties determined by different characterization techniques. In addition, the catalytic performance results were compared with those of a Ni catalyst obtained by conventional impregnation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetrapropyllamium hydroxid (TPAOH, 1.0 M solution in water) of Sigma Aldrich®, Sililica (SiO2) aerosil® 200 Degussa AG, Sodium Hydroxide (NaOH), Cicarelli®, Ludox® AS-40 colloidal silica, sodium aluminate (Na2Al2O4), Riedel-de-Haën, ethylenediamine (NH2CH2CH2NH2), Cicarelli®, nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), Cicarelli®. 2.2 Preparation of the silicalite-1 seeds For the synthesis of the silicalite seed, 6.12 g of Aerosil (fumed silica) was mixed with 3.12 g of water, to which a mixture of 24.89 g of TPAOH, 0.35 g of NaOH, and 1.04 g of DI water was then added [24]. The mixture was stirred for 24 h at 80 °C. Once the process was completed, the content was transferred to an autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 8 h. Then, the reactor was cooled and immediately removed from the oven. The resulting suspension was washed with DI water until pH=7, through centrifugation at 12,000 rpm for 30 min; the concentration of the resulting suspension was 0.1 g/mL. 2.3 Ni-ZSM-5 catalyst The catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis without using a structuring agent, for which the ZSM-5 zeolite synthesis method was modified by adding silicalite seeds. In the first set of experiments, the synthesis of pure ZSM-5 zeolite was optimized. The ZSM-5 powder was synthesized by mixing 0.81 g of Na2Al2O4 and 16.55 g of DI water (solution A), and on the other hand, 18.55 g of Ludox, 0.59 g of NaOH, and 16.55 g of DI water (solution B). Each mixture was stirred at 350 rpm for 15 min. After that, solution B was added to solution A, and the precursor mixture of molar composition 1SiO2:0.024Al2O3:0.14Na2O:20H2O was stirred at room temperature for 5 h with an addition of 0.6 g of silicalite-1 seeds. Finally, the hydrothermal synthesis was conducted in an autoclave at 180 °C for 24 h. The solid was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 24 h. The synthesis of the Ni-ZSM-5 catalysts was carried out by the in-situ incorporation method. The preparation of the synthesis gel was similar to that described for the pure ZSM-5 zeolite (stirring times and the seeds' incorporation) but considering the addition of the active phase in the silicon source. The Ni precursor solution was prepared by dissolving different theoretical loadings (1–5 wt.%) of NiCl2‧6H2O in DI water and ethylenediamine (EDA) (65 %). For a typical synthesis, NiCl2‧6H2O was dissolved in DI water (3 mL), and ethylenediamine (2 mL) was added. The solution was agitated by magnetic stirring (350 rpm) for 15 min. The formed complex [Ni(NH2CH2CH2NH2)2](Cl)2 was added dropwise to the synthesis gel. The effect of the synthesis time (between 24 and 144 h) was evaluated to obtain Ni catalysts with high crystallinity. The nomenclature used for the catalysts was Ni(x)-ZSM-5, where x represents the Ni loading (wt.%) determined by XRF (see Table 1 ). For comparison purposes, a Ni catalyst with 1.3 wt.% loading on ZSM-5 Zeolites (Si/Al ∼12) was prepared by the incipient-wetness impregnation method using NiCl2·6H2O as a precursor. The precursor solution was added drop by drop to the ZSM-5 zeolite previously treated at 300 °C for 6 h in an inert Ar atmosphere. After impregnation, the material was dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, it was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in air. The impregnated catalyst was labeled Ni1.3/ZSM5-i. 2.4 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the catalysts were taken with an Empyrean Panalytical Diffractometer, equipped with a CuKα source (λ = 1.540598 Å) for diffraction angles between 5 and 80° at 2θ with a scan step of 0.05°. The size of the crystallite was calculated from the Scherrer equation: (5) D = K λ β c o s θ Where D is the average crystallite size, K is a constant (0.9), λ is the radiation wavelength, 0.1540598 nm, θ is the Bragg angle, and β is the breadth of the peak. Eq. (6) was utilized to determine the crystallinity index of the catalysts; I (d501 at 23.02° and d051 at 23.23°) corresponds to the peak intensity for Ni-ZSM-5, and I0 is the intensity concerning ZSM-5 used as reference material. (6) I = ( I I 0 ) * 100 % Field emission scanning electron microscope. The morphology of the catalysts was analyzed using a Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM FIB) with a high-current and high-resolution FIB column, model Crossbeam 350, brand Carl ZEISS. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Microscope (JEOL model TEM-2100 plus) with high resolution, maximum acceleration voltage of 200 kV, step control, and minimum voltage of 20 kV. Previously, the fresh catalyst sample was reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere at a flow of 30 mL min−1 at 700 °C for 2 h in a quartz reactor. The reduced sample was deposited on a copper grid of the microscope. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission (STEM-HAADF) was also used to analyze the samples. X-ray fluorescence (XRF). An X-ray fluorescence spectrometer, Shimadzu brand, was used to determine the percentage of nickel in the catalysts. The spectrometer was equipped with an energy dispersion system (Model EDX-720) and operated at 50 kV at 100 µA. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). Approximately 80 mg of each sample was pretreated in a quartz reactor. The sample was treated in a N2 atmosphere at 200 °C for 2 h, then heated from room temperature to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C‧min−1, at a flow of 10 vol%. H2/Ar (40 mL min−1). A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) gas chromatograph was used to determine hydrogen consumption. Textural properties. Before the measurements, the samples were calcined ex-situ at 550 °C for 6 h in an air atmosphere. Following this, the samples were degassed at 120 °C for 12 h. Adsorption-desorption of N2 at −196 °C was performed at Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) for the calculation of the surface area, and through the αs-plot method (N2 at −196 °C), the volume of the micropore was calculated, using a micrometric equipment ASAP 2000. The pore size distribution (PSD) was obtained by the NLDFT method using the adsorption branch of the nitrogen isotherms. Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS). Raman spectroscopy measurements were determined using a LabRam spectrometer (Horiba-Jobin-Yvon) with a CCD detector coupled to an Olympus confocal microscope. A laser with a power of 5 Mw and an excitation wavelength of 532 nm (diode pump solid-state laser) was used. The measurements were carried out with a collection time of 10 s and 10 accumulations. Thermogravimetric analysis. Thermal analysis was applied to determine the carbon content of the used catalysts. Approximately 15 mg were placed in an alumina capsule and heated from room temperature at 850 °C using a TGA DTG-60 equipment Shimadzu, with a heating ramp of 10 °C min−1, in an air atmosphere (50 mL‧min−1). X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). XPS measurements of the reduced and used catalyst were performed using a multi-technique SPECS equipment. The data were collected with an AlKα X-ray source using an analyzer pass energy of 30 eV. The spectra were obtained at 200 W and 12 kV. The analyses were carried out on the reduced solids, and they were also treated in the load lock chamber attached to the spectrometer in H2(5 %)/Ar flow for 10 min at 400 °C. Al 2p, Ni 2p, Ni 3p, Si 2p, Si 2 s, Al 2p, Na 1 s core-level regions were analyzed. The collected data were processed using the CasaXPS program (Casa Software Ltd., UK), and the peak area integration was carried out using the Shirley-type background. The C1s binding energy at 284.6 eV was used as the reference binding energies. The surface atomic ratio was determined from the integration area and the sensitivity factor. Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFT). In situ DRIFT measurements were performed on IRPrestige-21 equipment, with a 32 × 3 mm ZnSe window and an MCT-M detector using liquid nitrogen. For the experiment, 5.3 mg of the sample was loaded into a porous ceramic capsule, and the spectra were collected with 4 cm−1 spectral resolution in a high-temperature and pressure cell (DiffusIRTM diffuse reflectance accessory). The sample was previously heated to 700 °C in a nitrogen atmosphere and then reduced in situ using an H2(5 %)/Ar mixture for 1 h. The DRM reaction was evaluated by feeding a mixture of 10 % CH4 and 10 % CO2 (balances in Ar) for a total flow rate of 50 mL min−1(W/F = 1.7 × 10−3 g cat·h·L−1). Subsequently, the temperature was lowered to 450 °C, and the spectra were recorded with temperature increases every 25 °C up to 700 °C. Finally, in isothermal mode at 700 °C, spectra were taken at 1, 5, 10, 15 and 20 min. 2.5 Catalytic tests The catalysts were evaluated in the dry reforming of methane using a quartz tubular fixed-bed reactor operated at atmospheric pressure, an isothermal regime (700 °C), and a space velocity equal to 0.062 g cat·h·L−1. Under these conditions, the effect of the Ni content was analyzed using a mass of 225 mg. For the catalyst with the best performance, an experiment was carried out in conditions far from the equilibrium, using a W/F = 0.031 g cat·h·L−1, equivalent to a mass of 112.5 mg. Before evaluation, the catalysts were calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in air flow. The catalysts were diluted in quartz (70 mesh) in a 1:1 ratio for the catalytic tests. The reactor was heated at 1 °C min−1 from room temperature to 700 °C under argon flow. Subsequently, the catalyst was reduced using hydrogen for 2 h. A reaction mixture of CH4:CO2:Ar = 1:1:2 was used, with a total feed flow of 60 mL⋅min−1. The reaction products were analyzed by online gas chromatography using two chromatographs: a Shimadzu GC-8A with a Porapak column and an SRI 8610C with a molecular sieve column, both equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The CH4 and CO2 conversions were calculated according to the following equations: (7) X C H 4 ( % ) = F C H 4 ( i n ) − F C H 4 ( o u t ) F C H 4 ( i n ) * 100 (8) X C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 ( i n ) − F C O 2 ( o u t ) F C O 2 ( i n ) * 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization Seed-induced zeolite synthesis has been presented as an improved alternative to the development of zeolite materials, allowing the preparation of different zeolite structures without adding a structure-directing agent [25,26]. For most zeolite synthesis, quaternary ammonium cations are used as templates; therefore, their removal by calcination generates dangerous gases (CO2 and NOx), energy consumption, and the possible degradation of the zeolite structure [27]. Therefore, an alternative to the synthesis of zeolites has been sought through seed syntheses [28]. To be used as seeds for the ZSM-5 zeolite synthesis, a colloidal suspension of silicalite nanoparticles was synthesized with a hydrodynamic particle size of ∼50 nm, as could be seen in Fig. 1S. As it is known, the absolute value of zeta potential is a suitable parameter for determining the stability of nanoparticle suspensions, considering that suspensions with zeta potential higher than 30 exhibit improved stability [29]. The measured zeta potential values for the silicalite suspension prepared were around 34 mV, indicating a stable dispersion. As observed in Fig. 1 , the ZSM-5 zeolite prepared by hydrothermal synthesis during 24 h presents a crystalline structure with characteristic diffraction peaks related to the zeolite with the MFI framework (JCPDS N° 00–042–0024) [30]. Note that the primary reflections located at 2θ= 21.81° (203), 22.25° (430), 23.18° (501), 23.32° (051), 23.74° (151), 23.99° (303), and 24.25° (133), were observed, showing a random orientation of the zeolite crystals (Fig. 1a). Comparing the XRD pattern of the synthesized zeolite and the reference pattern, it was possible to observe a pure MFI phase with the absence of impurities or other zeolite phases. This indicates that the use of silicalite-1 seeds allows us to synthesize a pure ZSM-5 zeolite with high crystallinity (Fig. 1a). Different synthesis times between 24 h and 144 h were analyzed to optimize the nickel incorporation in the zeolite structure reaching high crystallinity. For the sample prepared with low Ni content into the synthesis gel (0.6 wt. %), diffraction patterns of the MFI structure with high crystallinity were observed after 72 h of hydrothermal treatment, as shown in Fig. 1a. Note that, for the sample prepared with 0.6 wt %. of Ni in the gel, the I/I0 ratio increases with synthesis time from 25 to 100 for 24 h and 72 h, respectively. However, at higher Ni loadings in the gel (between 1.6 - 5 wt. %), amorphous powders were obtained after 72 h of synthesis (Fig. 1a sample Ni-0.7-ZSM-5), requiring 144 h to reach samples with high crystallinity (Fig. 1b). The XRD patterns of the samples prepared by hydrothermal treatment for 144 h showed the characteristic reflections of the ZSM-5 structure with a high crystallinity index (I/Io) (Fig. 1b). Note that in none of the cases, characteristic peaks of NiO were observed in the patterns (2θ = 37.33°, 43.38°, and 63.02°; NiO-PDF 01–073–1519), even after calcination at 550 °C (Fig. 2S), which could indicate a high dispersion of Ni particles on the zeolite [31]. On the other hand, for the sample prepared by the incipient wet impregnation method, the Ni-ZSM-5-i catalyst, the XRD pattern after calcination exhibited the peak corresponding to the (111) plane of NiO. This is probably due to a lower dispersion of nickel in this sample (Fig. 2S). The crystallite size calculated using the Scherrer equation for this catalyst presents a value of 13.3 nm. The peaks associated with the (200) and (220) planes were undetected. As a distinctive feature, note that in the diffraction patterns, the low-intensity peaks located at 2θ = 21.81° (203) and 22.25° (340) exhibited a change in the peak intensity ratio when nickel was incorporated directly into the synthesis gel (Fig. 2 ). The I(203) /I(340) intensity ratio was 0.35, and 1.46 for the pure ZSM-5 and the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 samples, respectively. By increasing the Ni content in the synthesis gel, the I(203) /I(340) intensity ratio increased up to a Ni content of 3 wt.% in the gel; when a 5.0 wt.% of nickel was added, the ratio decreased to 0.81. The change in the intensity ratio of these reflections could be related to incorporating nickel into the zeolite structure to a certain extent. Changes in the intensity ratio of characteristic reflections have been reported upon incorporation or cation exchange in different zeolites [32]. The bulk composition of the catalyst was determined by XRF measurements, while the surface composition was analyzed by XPS. The compositional analysis of the fresh catalysts is shown in Table 1, in which it can be observed that the bulk composition confirmed the presence of Ni in the ZSM-5 structure. The Si/Al atomic composition on the catalysts (Si/Al∼17) was likely the same as the Si/Al ratio determined in the pure ZSM-5 sample. To compare the extent of Ni incorporation on the catalyst, Fig. 3Sa shows the Ni wt.% of the catalysts determined by XRF as a function of the composition in the synthesis gel. It is important to note that, for all catalysts, except for the Ni0.6-ZSM-5 solid, the nickel content in the powder was lower than the nominal load in the synthesis gel. It was also possible to observe that at higher metal concentrations in the synthesis gel (3–5 wt.%), the nickel composition in the catalyst increased but was always below the Ni composition in the gel. Several studies have reported complete incorporation of the metal at low loadings (∼1 – 5wt.%) within zeolites [11]; however, when the ligand content increases, amorphous solids are obtained [33]. Wang et al. [34] reported the incorporation of 4.8 wt.% of Ni in the ZSM-5 zeolite, which was close to the nominal value (5wt.%), using ethylenediamine as a ligand. On the other hand, when the Ni/Al atomic surface ratio was analyzed by XPS, an atomic ratio significantly lower than the bulk composition was determined, which could indicate that only a smaller fraction of the Ni content was present on the surface of the zeolite crystals (Fig. 3S) or a high dispersion of the Ni particles. This observation agrees with the XRD data, where a change in the intensity ratio of the (203) and (340) reflections was evidenced, suggesting a change in the zeolite structure upon the incorporation of Ni (Fig. 3S). The XPS results suggest that in addition to metallic Ni, two different Ni2+ species were present on the surface of the catalyst. The Ni 2p3/2 region, of the reduced catalyst shows the contribution of four peaks at 853.0 eV, 855.3 eV, 857.5 eV, and 860.8 eV (Fig. 4S). These binding energies could be related to Ni0, two Ni2+ species with different environments, and the Ni shake-up satellite, respectively. The presence of NiO (855.3 eV, a small contribution) indicates that surface re-oxidation could occur during sample handling before introduction into the spectrometer, species that are not easily reduced at 400 °C in the pre-treatment chamber. Note that the catalyst with 2 wt.% of Ni presents a higher contribution of Ni0 (Ni0/Nitotal equal to 0.55 and 0.44 for the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 and Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst, respectively), indicating a higher proportion of easily reducible species on this solid. The TPR profiles of the catalysts showed broad hydrogen consumption peaks in the temperature range between 450 and 850 °C (Fig. 3 ), exhibiting a complete reduction below 850 °C. The Ni2.0-ZSM-5 catalyst presented a reduction peak at 508 °C, which could be assigned to the reduction of NiO in bulk or at the surface interacting weakly with the support [35]. This peak was not observed in the catalyst with lower Ni content, Ni0.7-ZSM-5, and Ni1.3-ZSM-5. From the curve fitting of the TPR profile of the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 sample, considering Gaussian fits, additional contributions appeared at 545 °C, 668.0 °C, and 778.4 °C. These high-temperature peaks can be associated with the formation of nickel species with strong interactions with the zeolite framework [36]. On the other hand, for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst, these reduction peaks were observed at lower temperatures, 548.4 °C, 608.4 °C, and 694.4 °C. These data agree with the XPS results, where a higher contribution of easily reducible species was observed in the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 solid. Ismaila et al. [37]. reported reduction temperatures of around 790 °C for Ni species encapsulated in silicalite (Ni@Si-1) and 465 °C for a catalyst obtained by the impregnation method (Ni/Si-1). The high reduction temperature for the catalyst prepared by the one-pot method was attributed to a higher resistance of the NiO phase to thermal reduction due to a higher interaction between the encapsulated nickel and the S-1 structure. For the catalyst prepared by impregnation (Ni1.3/ZSM-5-i), a total reduction was observed at lower temperatures (385.5 °C and 518.3 °C), suggesting a lower interaction between nickel and the support (Fig. 3d). Several authors [38] have reported two groups of reduction peaks for Ni-zeolite catalysts, low temperatures peaks (between 300 and 450 °C) and peaks at high temperatures (between 450 and 700 °C), attributed to NiO with weak and strong interaction with zeolite surface, respectively. Also, reduction signals above 600 °C were related to Ni2+ cations inside the zeolite framework [39]. Comparing the catalysts prepared with the same metal loading but using different methods (Ni1.3/ZSM-5-i and Ni1.3-ZSM-5), it is possible to observe signals at temperatures higher than 500 °C in both solids. However, the impregnated solid exhibited only a small contribution of a peak at 518 °C compared with the mare intense peak located at lower temperatures, suggesting that a major contribution of NiO with low Ni-support interaction is present in this sample. The textural characteristics of the catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts belong to type I and IV isotherms due to intracrystalline micropores and mesopores in the structure (Fig. 4Sa). A slight decrease in the micropores' surface area and volume were observed with the incorporation of nickel. The Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst (SBET=290 m2 g−1 and VµP=0.08 cm3 g−1) presented a greater decrease with respect to the ZSM-5 zeolite (SBET=380 m2 g−1 and VµP= 0.12 cm3 g−1). The decrease in micropore volume could probably be due to the incorporated nickel that partially blocked the pores of the ZSM-5 zeolite [19]. Note that this observation agrees with the change in the I(203) /I(340) peak intensity ratio seen in the XRD patterns, where a higher change was reported for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 2). A nickel concentration of 3 wt.% in the synthesis gel probably allowed the incorporation of more nickel into the zeolite framework under the conditions studied. A higher concentration could induce the development of nickel particles with a higher size, bringing about their deposition on the surface of the crystals instead of their incorporation into the zeolite framework. On the other hand, the volume of the mesopores increased significantly from 0.08 cm3 g−1 to 0.19 cm3 g−1 with the nickel loading (1.6–3.0 wt.%), consequently increasing the total pore volume (VTP). This is probably due to the distortion of the mesopores due to the presence of nickel that generates larger pores, increasing mesoporosity. The pore size distribution calculated by the NLDFT method shows a distribution ranging from 1 to 7 nm, including micropores to mesopores. (Fig. 4Sb). Besides, Li et al. [38] synthesized Ni@ZSM-5 catalysts through one-pot, with loadings 4 wt. %, and reported the presence of pore sizes ∼0.5 nm and ∼2 nm, attributed to intercrystalline micropores and mesopores, respectively. The morphology of the synthesized catalysts was analyzed using FE-SEM analysis. In Fig. 5S, it is possible to observe a coffin-like morphology, characteristic of MFI zeolite crystals with random orientation. Zeolite crystals of different sizes can be noticed, some larger than ∼300 nm and others smaller, between 50 and 100 nm. From the comparative images of the three catalysts, no significant changes in morphology were evidenced with increasing nickel loads. Fig. 4 shows the TEM micrographs and the particle size distribution for the reduced catalysts. The analysis of the particle size distribution was determined to be around 10.8 ± 2.8 nm for the catalyst with 2 wt.% (inset: Ni nanoparticle size distribution of Ni2.0-ZSM-5). As shown in Fig. 4b, some particles between 5 and 18 nm in size (yellow circles) can be observed on the surface of the zeolite, as evidenced by the STEM-HAADF analysis of the solid (Fig. 4e and f, for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5, and Ni2.0-ZSM-5, respectively). The presence of these particles can be related to the lower temperature reduction peak shown in the TPR profiles (Fig. 3), being particles that interact weakly with the zeolite. On the other hand, on the catalyst with 1.3 wt.% of nickel, it was not possible to measure a significant number of Ni particles; therefore, a particle size distribution could not be obtained. However, it was possible to observe some Ni particles lower than 10 nm. Notwithstanding, the Fast Fourier transform (FFT) analysis for the interplanar distances in different sample regions indicates characteristic interplanar distances of reduced nickel on the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst. The interplanar fringes spacing, i.e., d–spacing of the (200) and (111) reflection planes, was calculated by fast Fourier Transform (FFT) using GATAN software. The calculated d-spacing was 0.176 and 0.205 nm, consistent with metallic Ni on the catalyst (Fig. 4c and d), according to the crystallographic card 00–004–0850. On the other hand, some nickel oxidized particles were observed in the sample, showing an interplanar distance of 0.250 nm, assigned to the (200) reflection plane (card 01–073–1519). 3.2 Catalytic testing Fig. 5 shows the catalytic evaluation of the Ni(x)-ZSM-5 catalysts in the dry reforming of methane at 700 °C, CH4/CO2=1.0 and W/F = 0.062 g cat·h·L−1. The equilibrium conversions calculated using the STANJAN software are also presented in Fig. 5 for comparison. A relationship between the activity and nickel loading incorporated in the zeolites can be observed. Note that all the catalysts were active for the DRM, showing the catalyst with the highest nickel content (Ni2.0-ZSM-5) conversions of 67 and 74 % for CH4 and CO2, respectively. In the case of the catalyst with lower Ni content (0.7 %), the CO2 and CH4 conversions decreased during all reaction times. On the other hand, the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst showed deactivation during the first 6 h of reactions, achieving conversions of 47 % and 59 % for CH4 and CO2, respectively, and maintaining it during 24 h of reaction. It is important to note that the conversions reached with the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst were higher than those obtained with the impregnated catalyst (CO2=34.6 %, CH4=24.4 %) with the same Ni loading, which also exhibited more significant deactivation. Fig. 6S shows the H2/CO ratio for all catalysts; note that the catalyst with the highest Ni loading (2.0 %) showed a higher H2/CO ratio during the first 2 h of reaction than expected to the thermodynamic equilibrium (H2/CO ratio= 0.91), which was calculated using the STANJAN (without considering the formation of carbonaceous deposits). This would indicate that in the case of the catalysts with higher Ni load (Ni2.0-ZSM-5), in addition to the dry reforming reaction, the methane decomposition reaction could occur simultaneously (CH4 ⇌ C+2H2 [40]), thus giving rise to the formation of carbonaceous deposits. In this sense, Xu et al. reported that the H2/CO ratio in catalysts obtained by Ni encapsulated in silicalite-1 (at temperatures between 550 and 700 °C) increased at high temperatures due to DRM and/or the encouraged methane cracking reaction [41]. Therefore, a trend towards the expected thermodynamic ratio of 1 indicated the formation of pure synthesis gas and less coke formation [42]. On the other hand, the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited an H2/CO ratio slightly below the thermodynamic ratio over the complete test, while for the impregnated catalyst, this ratio was lower. According to the thermodynamic data [43] at 700 °C and 1 atm, the dry reforming (Eq. (1)) and methane decomposition (Eq. (2)) reactions are favored, and to a lesser extent, the reverse reaction of water gas (Eq. (3)) could occur. The catalysts with higher Ni content (Ni2.0-ZSM-5 and Ni1.3-ZSM-5) were evaluated under conditions far from the thermodynamic equilibrium to analyze their stability. These solids were assessed using a W/F = 0.031 g cat·h·L−1. Under these conditions, the CH4 and CO2 conversions (Fig. 6 a and b) were 49.76 % (CO2) and 39.5 % (CH4) for the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 catalyst, and 44.9 % (CO2) and 30.3 % (CH4) for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst after five hours of reaction, remaining in these values after 24 h (Fig. 6a and b). Therefore, Fig. 6a and b show that the CO2 and CH4 conversions decreased during the first hours by only 25 %, maintaining their activity after 24 h of reaction, demonstrating the stability of the catalysts. Note that the catalyst with 1.3 wt. % of Ni showed conversions similar to those of the solid with 2.0 wt. % under the analyzed conditions, showing a higher activity per gram of Ni, 8.4 and 7.1 molCH4 g−1 Ni h−1, for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 and Ni2.0-ZSM-5 catalyst, respectively. The superior activity per gram of Ni of the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst could be attributed to the greater confinement of Ni crystallites within the support, which improved metal support interaction, as suggested by the TPR (Fig. 3) and XPS results. Considering these results, the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst was evaluated for 48 h under reaction conditions (Fig. 7 ). Note that after 48 h, the catalyst maintained the activity at 60 % of the initial value (Fig. 7). The slight deactivation by this material was probably due to the blockage of the Ni active site by carbon deposition or the occurrence of active phase sintering. In situ characterization. DRIFT measurements for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst were performed at 450 °C for 25 min. Fig. 8 a shows the Drift spectra during DRM as a function of reaction time. The spectra show characteristic vibration frequencies of the feed gases, i.e., methane, with a band at 3012 cm−1, and CO2 between 2349 and 2306 cm−1 [44]. It has been reported that the first step for the dry reforming of methane initially involves the dehydrogenation of methane to give absorbed CHx species [45], which can be related to the bands observed at 2943 and 2893 cm−1, associated to the C−H stretching characteristic of C H 2 * and C H 3 * intermediates [46,47]. Also, the bands at 2943 cm−1 associated with asymmetric stretching of COO and bending vibration of C−H bond were observed [48]. The second step corresponds to the dissociative adsorption of CO2 that generates adsorbed active oxygen species, and CO. Analysis by DRIFT shows the formation of carbonyl groups, which reveal the dissociation of CO2 at the nickel sites. The bands appearing at 2020–2050 cm−1 indicate the formation of linearly adsorbed CO (Ni−COads-lin), and those at 1920–1860 cm−1 for (Ni−COads-br) bridged CO species suggesting that CO2 is dissociated into CO and “O” species. Some studies propose that CO2 is adsorbed on the support, or the metal-support interface forming carbonate surface species. On the other hand, due to the reactive absorption of CO, the formation of carbonate species ( C O 3 2 − ), bicarbonates ( H C O 3 − ), carboxylates ( C O O − ) and formates ( H C O O − ) could occur. Note that under the analyzed conditions, band characteristic of carbonate and formats were identified in spectra. First, at low wavenumber, a band at 870 cm−1 was identified, attributed to vibrations of carbonite ions (νs( C O 2 2 )) [49]. Recently, Azancot et al. reported the possibility of forming carbonite ions due to the interaction of CO with the most basic O2− sites of the support, and subsequently, the formation of carbonates, with the excess of CO, [50]. Additionally, a broad band associated to carbonates ( C O 3 2 − ) at 1460 cm−1 was found on the catalyst surface [51]. Other vibrational mode (νas(COO−)) characteristic of formate species was also identified by the presence of the band at 1605–1540 cm−1. The carbonate species at the catalyst's surface could be reduced to formate species. The DRIFT analysis for the DRM as a function of temperature is shown in Fig. 8b. By increasing the reaction temperature from 450 °C-700 °C, a greater conversion of both CH4 and CO2 is obtained and, therefore, is reflected in the decrease in the intensity of their characteristic bands (3012 and 2357 cm −1). Also, increasing the temperature decreases the intensity of the bands associated with CO adsorption on metal sites (between 2017 and 1878 cm−1). The intensity of the characteristic bands associated with CHx species (2943 and 2893 cm−1) did not significantly change with the temperature increment up to 700 °C, showing the CH4 activation over the entire temperature analyzed. Table 3 summarizes different zeolite-based catalysts applied in the dry reforming of methane reported in the literature. Although the evaluation conditions differ between the different solids, which makes it challenging to make a direct comparison between them, it is possible to conclude that the activity presented in the material studied in this work is comparable with that reported in other studies operating under more favorable conditions [52,53]. On the other hand, it is important to highlight that the material based on Ni1.3-ZSM-5 has the lowest percentage of the active phase, which allows us to conclude that it is a promising material that deserves further exploration, seeking to increase the rate of the encapsulated metal. Also, note that the stability of some materials [40,53,52] does not exceed 20 h of reaction, presenting a more significant formation of carbonaceous deposits when evaluated in shorter reaction times than the material studied in this work. 3.3 Characterization of used catalysts The Raman spectra of the used catalysts (Fig. 9 a) show two vibration bands: a d-band, assigned to the disordered carbon species at 1344 cm−1, which is associated with the presence of sp3 hybridization of amorphous carbon, and a G-band of graphitized carbon at 1580 cm−1 for the sp2 hybridization of graphitic carbon [56,57]. These data show that under the analyzed reaction conditions, coke formation occurs for the three catalysts. Note that by studying the D and G bands, it is possible to observe that the (ID/IG) intensity ratio is similar for higher Ni content in the catalyst: Ni2.0-ZSM-5 (ID/IG =0.63), Ni1.3-ZSM-5 (ID/IG =0.59), increasing the ratio (ID/IG =1.98) at lower loading for the catalyst Ni0.7-ZSM-5. The increase in the ratio between the D and G bands indicates a low degree of graphitization, as reported in the literature [58,59,60]. An additional 2D band (2699 cm−1) was detected for the catalysts with a higher percentage of Ni (2.0 wt.% and 1.3 wt.%), which is characteristic of sp2 carbon networks [61]. Fig. 9b shows the thermogravimetric analysis of the used catalysts. All catalysts show a mass loss between 400 °C and 800 °C, associated with the oxidation of different types of carbon. The mass loss of the used catalysts was 0.07 %, 0.09 %, and 0.17 % for the Ni0.7-ZSM-5, Ni1.3-ZSM-5, and Ni2.0-ZSM-5 catalysts, respectively. Therefore, the decrease in the activity of the catalysts could be associated with the blocking of the active sites due to the presence of carbon. It is known that methane decomposition and CO disproportionation are the main paths of carbon deposition, with the latter being disfavored by the increase in temperature [62]. Consequently, under the experimental conditions studied in this work, the formation of carbonaceous deposits could originate mainly from the decomposition of methane [63]. Chaudhary et al. [64] studied Ni and NiCe/ZSM-5 catalysts in the DRM at 700 °C. The authors determined a decrease in the activity over 12 h on stream, claiming that successive carbon deposition at the active sites due to methane decomposition occurred. The thermogravimetric analysis of the used solids showed a 28.47 % and 23.65 % weight loss for the NiCe/ZSM-5 and Ni/ZSM-5 catalysts, respectively. On the other hand, Fonseca et al. [65] studied Ni/Al2O3 catalysts with different Ni loading, showing that those with higher performance were those with Ni loadings between 15 and 20 wt. %. However, these solids exhibited coke formation (between 4 and 5 %), which was associated with the Ni crystallite size. The Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst studied in this work shows lower carbon formation (0.09 %) than the Ni/Al2O3 and another catalyst of Ni/ZSM-5 prepared for impregnation. The TEM micrographs of the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 and Ni1.3-ZSM-5 used catalysts (after reaction at W/F = 0.062 g cat·h ·L−1) show the presence of carbon filaments with external diameters of ∼50 nm, formed on the surface of the catalysts (Fig. 10 ). It has been reported that these structures come from the deposition of carbon on the back of the Ni metal crystallites, which causes the metal particles to move away from the support, as evidenced for the catalyst with a loading of 2.0 wt.% (Fig. 10b), showing an average particle size of around ∼36 nm. On the other hand, on the catalyst with 1.3 wt.%, only the formation of crimped filaments was observed without observation of free Ni particles. However, some Ni particles can be identified through FFT analysis, with sizes of ∼21 nm, on which the carbon filaments are anchored (Fig. 10d). Under the reaction conditions analyzed in this work (T = 700 °C), the formation of carbonaceous residues could originate mainly from the dehydrogenation of methane. Several publications reported a mechanism for carbon formation based on the catalytic activity of Ni particles, proposing that the growth of carbon filaments occurs mainly by diffusion of carbon from the bulk to the surface of the particles [66,67]. On the other hand, recent reports analyzed the mechanism for carbon formation using DFT calculations [68]. These studies stated that carbon deposition on Ni-based catalysts is structure-sensitive, concluding that fine-tuning the crystalline phases, morphology, particle size, and the coordination of Ni is necessary to balance the high activity and stability of the catalyst. In the micrographs obtained by HRTEM (Fig. 7Sa and b), the determination of the spacing between the crystalline planes was carried out for the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 and Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalysts and Ni1.3-ZSM-5. The application of the mask to the FFT and the inverse FFT calculation (FFT−1) shows a clear image of the arrangement of the interplanar distances observed. The insets presented in Fig. 7S show the FFT, FFT with mask, and its subsequent FFT −1 of the selected area. These lattice fringes of the carbon filaments indicate a high degree of graphitization, in agreement with the Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 9a). The calculated value is 0.37 nm, which agrees with the (002) lattice plane of species-derived from graphite carbon [69]. It has been reported that Ni active sites may present a favorable electron structure for the activation and cleavage of the C–H bonds, which is a fundamental step for CH4 activation [70]. On the other hand, when CO2 reaches the reaction sites slowly, the polymerization of CH4-x can occur, leading to the formation of carbon deposits on the catalyst [71]. Han et al. [72] reported that the carbon deposition process requires larger Ni ensembles, suggesting that a high dispersion of Ni on suitable support can limit Ni particle size and subsequently prevent carbon deposition, allowing to expose more active sites for the DRM reaction [8]. In this sense, the use of zeolites as supports is particularly effective, offering a large surface area and a microporous framework that promotes a high dispersion of Ni, enhances metal-support interaction, and minimizes coke deposition [73]. In this work, the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst presented Ni particles lower than 10 nm and a low carbon formation under DRM. Also, in the Drift experiments, it was shown that at 700 °C, the bands corresponding to the CHX species (2943 and 2893 cm−1) were observed, slightly increasing with reaction time. From these observations, it can be inferred that in the reaction mechanism of the Nix-ZSM-5 catalyst, the CHX species formed in the active sites are oxidized by CO2 species, which would be favored due to the relatively small sizes of the Ni particles, and the interaction of the metal with the support. The XRD results of the used catalysts show the characteristic peaks of the MFI zeolite structure (Fig. 11 ), indicating the structure's thermal stability during reaction at high temperatures. By XRD measurements of the reduced samples, it was possible to detect the presence of metallic Ni on the catalysts (Fig. 11, amplified patterns). The analysis shows diffraction peaks corresponding to the (111) reflection plane of Ni at 2θ equal to 44.7° and (200) at 51.8°, according to the Ni-PDF 04–0850 crystallographic card. These data suggest that sintering processes occurred under the reduction of the catalysts, probably due to the thermal diffusion of metallic Ni particles in the zeolite [56]. A fraction of the Ni particles located at the surface of the zeolite crystals probably sintered under reduction at high temperatures. On the other hand, even after calcination, characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to nickel species were not evident in the synthesized samples. After the reaction, the intensity of the diffraction peaks corresponding to metallic nickel increased, which was related to an increase in the crystallite size compared to the reduced material. The calculated crystallite size values are presented in Table 3. The average size of the Ni crystallites was determined from Scherrer's equation and the XRD patterns at 2θ = 44.7°. The XRD data agree with the TEM data (Fig. 4), where the presence of metallic nickel in the used catalysts was observed (Table 4 ). In brief, the slight deactivation of materials with a higher Ni load could be due to coke deposition on the Ni particles that are not encapsulated and/or to the sintering of these particles. In the case of the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst, the slight deactivation during the first hours of the reaction may be related to the sintering of the nickel particles that would be interacting weakly with the support. Remember that in this material, the presence of significant carbon deposits was not observed; in addition, through TPR and TEM, it was concluded that a greater proportion of particles would interact strongly with the support, suggesting the incorporation of nickel particles in the zeolite structure. 4 Conclusion Ni(x)-ZSM5 catalysts with different nickel loadings were synthesized through the direct incorporation of Ni into the synthesis gel. As the synthesis time increased, high crystallinity Ni-ZSM-5 catalysts were successfully obtained without adding a structuring agent. The one-pot hydrothermal synthesis allowed obtaining active catalysts for hydrogen production through the dry reforming of methane, showing the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst superior activity per gram of Ni. The slight deactivation of the Ni2.0-ZSM-5 solid could be related to coke deposition on the Ni particles located at the surface of the zeolite crystals and/or to the sintering of these particles, as observed by TEM. On the other hand, for the Ni1.3-ZSM-5 catalyst, the slight deactivation during the first hours of reaction may be mainly related to the sintering of the small fraction of nickel particles that would be interacting weakly with the support. The superior performance of this solid could be attributed to the greater confinement of Ni crystallites within the support, which improved the metal support interaction, as evidenced by TPR results and suggested by TEM. coredata.dc:description: Ni-ZSM-5 catalysts with different Ni loadings were synthesized by the one-pot method, using ethylenediamine as a complex agent to prevent precipitation during the hydrothermal synthesis. The effect of nickel content and synthesis time on the crystallinity of the solids was characterized by X-ray diffraction. The results showed that an increase in the synthesis time was needed to obtain catalysts with high crystallinity. The increment in the reduction temperature for the catalyst with lower Ni content indicated the formation of Ni species with higher interaction with the support. All the solids were active for the dry reforming of methane, showing the catalyst with 1.3 wt.% of Ni superior activity per gram of Ni and lower carbon formation. This catalyst was stable under the DRM reaction even after 48 h. The performance of this solid could be attributed to the greater confinement of Ni crystallites within the support, which improved metal support interaction, as evidenced by temperature-programmed reduction and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy and suggested by transmission electron microscopy.
